review_title: Decent Job, but difficult to balance with graduate school work
pros: - wonderful coworkers - flexible scheduling - job tasks were easy to pick up - job was fun, and closing shifts were very chill
cons: - minimal training - have to advocate for yourself or else your hours would start to creep up - low paying - high turnover

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Missoula, MT
pros: Wide range of areas of interest
cons: They are in age od senior.

pros: Awesome co-workers and flexibility for the job. Ability to learn many different avenues of the business within the Student Recreation.
cons: Pay was pretty low, especially with the background/experience had going into it.

review_title: Underpaid but great place to live and friendly colleagues for the most part
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Missoula, MT
pros: Great place to live and friendly colleagues for the most part. Decent facilities.
cons: Underpaid and lack of any sorts of benefits to compensate for the low pay.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Missoula, MT
pros: •The instructors I worked for provided a lot of latitude in allowing me to develop course content, hold office hours, and provide students with additional help as needed. • A very reasonable amount of work was assigned. • This is an excellent position for a graduate student, providing a tuition waiver and additional income, •I would highly reccomend such a position if you are considering graduate school at The University of Montana.
cons:
•The department I worked  for had a lot of personality conflicts, strife, and scandals, but the surviving faculty are excellent and committed to improving the department culture and replacing former faculty with high quality people. 
• I believe this department that I worked for will become a much better place to work in the coming years.

review_title: All the Pitfalls of Academia but none of the Benefits
pros: Beautiful area to live and this is one of the only major employers in the area.
cons: This university is resting on some laurels that were probably never actually earned in the first place. The people here think it is such a prestigious institution, yet, comparing it to other colleges in the US its mediocre, at best. Its like they all live in a bubble and haven't experienced the world outside.

review_title: Low wages, lots of flexibility, some good benefits
pros: Flexibility depending on your department Some community perks including events and groups to join Good benefits including health insurance and tuition waiver
cons: Executive leadership is out of touch and keeps getting rid of the people who make it function Pay is not good and limited ability to change classification for more pay Lots of ego in academia

pros: Beautiful campus, next to river
cons: Buildings old and need upgrades

pros: It has just perfect nature.
cons: Everything rather than nature is negative.

review_title: Nice work environment, some nice people, unsustainable pay.
job_title: Accounting Associate II in Missoula, MT
pros: - Forgiving work environment - Somewhat laid back - Management does seem to care about employees (but are relatively powerless) - Small bonuses were made available during Covid.
cons: - Severely unlivable wage ($0.50 cost of living adjustment during Covid, despite union) - Administration does NOT care about employees - Uncooperative and frequently unkind instructors (good professors do everything you need them to without prompting, only interactions are to follow up with professors who lag) - You will very likely end up doing your job and at least one other person's too - Very high turnover

pros: Don't work here. They treat employees horrible.
cons: No room for advancement here.

job_title: Assistant Director of Events in Missoula, MT
pros: - High Energy Team Environment - Flexibility (WFH when needed, ample days off) - Comradery and partnerships across campus - Working with students and families 1:1 - Leadership role with lots of autonomy, no micromanagement
cons: - Quite a bit of weekend work - Lack of staffing in the office/around campus, so less support during events - No goals set at the beginning of employment

pros: Love the students, they’re fantastic and wonderful to work with.
cons: Faculty, staff, and admin are more focused on internal politics, appearances, and nepotism than the interests of their students. It’s 2022 and retaliation for reporting is a real issue. With constant decreases in funding, it’s cutthroat and really traumatizing.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Missoula, MT
pros: Workload, flexible, at home, great professors
cons: Need additional job or loans to support pay

pros: Good job for student workers

review_title: Pretty meh but there are some perks

cons: Poor pay and little stability

pros: Working on campus is wonderful, great breaks for food, walks, and fresh air.
cons: Lots of red tape in hiring, don’t be surprised if hiring process takes months.

job_title: Information Technology Manager in Missoula, MT
pros:
- You can make a huge impact
- Big enough to allow professional growth, small enough to know most people
- Despite substantial revenue loss over the last decade, changes are being made in very positive directions
- Benefits are amazing
- Co-workers have always been great
- Leadership is approachable
- Supports LGBTQ+ as a matter of policy (the State of Montana does not have anti-discrimination laws for this community, so UM's policy is great to have)
cons:
- Parking is a challenge unless you pay for a private space or use the (very good) public transit
- Raises are negotiated with unions, so to earn more you have to get reclassified
- This organization is always understaffed and puts a heavy burden on talented employees
- Onboarding experience is highly variable, usually poor
- Diversity initiatives are still a work in progress

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Missoula, MT

cons: Not on par with the national average

pros: High research university with world class research faculty.
cons: Experienced enrollment drops in recent years. But slowly beginning to stabilize.

job_title: Director, Call Center Operations in Missoula, MT
pros: Extremely positive environment to work in. I love everything about my career at UM. My colleagues are professional, enthusiastic, and teamwork based people. We love what we do and where we do it. The COVID Prevention Team at UM has handled the pandemic better than anyplace I have seen.
cons:
The salaries can be a bit lower than other industries, but the perks of working at UM help to compensate for the lower salary. 

Some of the systems and database platforms are antiquated, which can cause inefficiencies, but UM is continuing to strive to improve these.

pros: Great culture with nice work/life balance.

review_title: Department is great, institution itself is bonkers
pros:
Amazing location! Missoula is great!
Specific college/department within which I teach is the best team of faculty with whom I’ve ever worked (I’ve taught at multiple institutions of higher learning in my career).
In reference to my stated con about UM, it seems like they’re trying to steer the ship in a new direction. Although is slow-going, and the onset of COVID certainly didn’t help speed up this process, I am hopeful the challenges we face working here are not a permanent situation.
cons: The University of Montana itself is one of the most frustrating institutions of higher learning I’ve experienced. As an institution it’s inefficient, imposing unnecessarily complicated policies and processes that affect morale from top to bottom.

review_title: Low pay, zero ability for advancement, but hey, nice scenery.
pros: Decent benefits which you'll receive even while only employed at 50% time. Tuition waiver for staff/faculty. Flexible hours are often available depending on your position. Missoula isn't a large city/town, so commute times are short. If you're not braindead you can work at 15% efficiency and still out-perform most of your coworkers. Most staff positions are unionized so you can't get fired.
cons: They tell you there's a career ladder but neglect to tell you there are no rungs on the ladder. Administration tearfully says a horrible economy means no raises for staff or faculty and vacated positions won't be filled, yet somehow keeps hiring new provosts and administrators with fancy titles to help them reach the "lofty" goals of the Strategic Plan. Nevermind the fact that the four year graduation rate is still 40% and certainly won't be helped by having grad students teach classes instead of adjunct and tenured faculty. Wages across the board for staff, adjunct, and tenured faculty are abysmal. Probably not a good sign when a department head has to teach summer school classes to pay their mortgage. If you're not braindead you'll get to pick up the slack in your department while the people who have worked there 20+ years under-perform and get paid twice as much as you do. Most staff positions are unionized so they can't get fired. And the student janitors will steal your food from the fridge.

review_title: Not Worth The Price or Pay
pros:
Relaxed environment
No Karens usually
Free meal with every 3 hour shift
cons:
Not enough pay for the amount of work
No tips
Managed poorly
Everything in the store is ridiculously expensive
VERY wasteful

review_title: Quality education rooted in western values
pros: Conveniently located, knowledgeable faculty, and tremendous resources.
cons: COVID-19 remote learning (obviously not at the fault of the university)

pros: Full benefits package, 2+ weeks vacation, job security
cons: Limited upward growth, no pay raises

review_title: Eager Recent Graduate of University of Montana
pros: Affordable, Great School, Great Atmosphere
cons: No Cons, No Negatives, No Comment

review_title: Small = great for students, OK for teachers
pros: Small classes, general flexibility on schedules, supportive admin as far as classroom needs and dealing with emergency cancelations.
cons: Admin runs scared from student critiques, which are bipolar at best in an area that runs the scale from Fundamentalist LDS to just left of Bernie all in one town. This makes for a difficult time as a prof teaching a constantly changing "audience" if the admin expects to cater to specific squeaky wheels. As an example, I was "coached" on complaints about what I wore, how I spoke about specific topics, and even for making accommodations to other students.  This is college, folks, at a public state uni - not high school where you can't talk about "inappropriate things" or a pay-to-graduate school where you are a client who has the right to demand something from an employee. So, that can be tiresome after a while, though the lovely admins were always very polite and sweet about it all.

review_title: An incredible place to work and to use as primary care for a student
job_title: Social Media Coordinator in Missoula, MT
pros: personable service and friendly people
cons: only open to University of Montana students

pros: Missoula is a great place to live
cons: Missoula is a challenging place to live. Expensive housing market and jobs that don't pay well.

pros: Liberal arts and research campus in a progressive community.
cons: Downturn in enrollment and continuous turn-over in adminstration.

job_title: IT Help Desk in Missoula, MT
pros:
Flexible schedules
Nice people
Consistent shifts
enough to get through school
cons: stressful, but not too bad

job_title: Data Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Positive experience and dedicated people
cons: A lot of monotonous work

review_title: You can't eat the scenery, or cut through the bureaucracy
pros: Location, location, location.  Missoula is beautiful.  And to be paid to live here is great.  If you love the outdoors you will love Missoula.  There's also great cultural opportunities for those who don't love the outdoors!  The campus is also quite lovely and the people are friendly and welcoming.
cons: The students are unmotivated, the salaries are pitiful, and the administration is clueless.  The current push to make UM a primarily graduate level institution is misguided at best and a disaster waiting to happen.  I have no idea why this is happening, who approved it, etc.  It seems to have just sprung out of Dennison and no one is brave enough to say it's a bad idea.

pros:
- Very laid back, supportive, easygoing work environment. I miss it.
- Faculty and staff were great to work with.
- Flexible scheduling.
- Campus is a great place to work with lots of amenities and is easy to commute to from most of town without a car. 
- I was able to travel around the state for work.
cons:
- Low pay for most student workers. You will make more money working somewhere in town.

- Most work-study jobs have you performing very menial tasks.  I once spent an entire two weeks of my work-study scraping price stickers off of thousands of hand clappers. 

- Your job usually ends when you graduate. Mine did not, and I turned it into a part-time job, but that was not common.

- Very limited parking, even with a permit.

review_title: I have learned a lot, but have done quite a bit of mundane work.
pros: It is a good learning environment where you are expected to work hard and keep up to date within your field.  There are many opportunities for pursuing your academic interests.  The schedule is flexible, and the people are good to work with.
cons: It is difficult to pursue research interests that are outside the interests of the professors working here, which I think is common.  I did not receive very good instruction on how to propose and successfully receive a grant.

pros: For my student custodial job, my supervisor made coming to work enjoyable, there was opportunity to pick up extra hours regularly and my coworkers were great!
cons: Not a lot of hours. You are looking at few hours a week though. 3.5 hours a way and 5 days a week is what I worked. Monday- Thursday was 8:00pm to 11:30pm and Friday was 4:30-8pm. This did constrain the classes I could take a little bit, as working a later shift will screw with your sleeping schedule.

review_title: A great place to make friends, learn important "real world" skills and how to give back to the community.
pros: You are only limited by your own creativity. KBGA is an integral part of the community and opens doors to meeting many influential people in Missoula. High respect for people that work at KBGA. See projects completed. team-oriented. great perks to compensate for low pay including coffee at work, and show tickets.
cons: low-pay. Long hours. Many events to attend that aren't paid. yearly managerial turn-over.  some people that are hired have zero experience so learning curve is high.

review_title: A great place to work in but very little job security makes it hard to stay on the job especially if you are an adjunct.
pros: First off, you will be working in a great campus. It is one of the most beautiful campuses across the country. You will enjoy your work environment. There are lots of friendly and helpful people in each department.
cons: There is unfortunately very little commitment towards adjunct faculty. The administration could decide to let you go any second with budget cuts that do not seem to end.

review_title: Location is beautiful, pay is just OK
pros: location, rate of pay fairly high by Missoula standards, faculty/staff perks such as free theater, discounts, etc, networking opportunities on campus, casual work environment, benefits can be good for full-time employees (which can help make up for so-so salaries)
cons: pay is still low, difficult to cut through bureaucracy, many new posted positions seem to already have candidates chosen, making advancement difficult, pretentious faculty create faculty/staff rift, staff feel under appreciated and overlooked (in addition to often being poorly paid)

review_title: Great place to work - however salaries are not competitive.
job_title: UC Communications Coordinator in Missoula, MT
pros: The University of Montana is an excellent place to work, fun, dynamic, incredible people. Relaxed work environment. Educational benefits are great.
cons: Politics, like any university. Sexism, especially in the staff sector. Salaries are very low. Accountability, let go of the people who are bringing the organization down, either through not doing their jobs, chronically overspending, or doing things they'd get fired for at any other job; it's time.

review_title: Good for students; Hit-or-miss with the managers
pros:
Flexible hours
Easy work
On-campus location
Relaxed work environment
cons:
They hire the first people to apply, not the best people (afraid to say no to applicants).
Managers  promote independence and time management to employees, and then get mad when employees are independent, self-starting workers.

review_title: University is a great place to leave as a staff member.
job_title: Manager of IT Colleges of Arts and Sciences in Missoula, MT
pros: Working with student employees and mentoring them into careers.  The scenary is nice.  Some of the faculty care about their jobs as instructing courses.
cons: The faculty union is weak in that for some of the positions at the University the staff are not even paid half of what they could make elsewhere.  Staff are treated like second rate citizens compared to the faculty.

pros: The staff of the Alumni Relations office at the University of Montana are professional, motivated, and fun. The working atmosphere was relaxed, but everyone took their jobs seriously and regarded their work as important. Collaboration was encouraged and good work acknowledged.
cons: The writer-editor position was part-time, but as a university employee, you are eligible for nearly all benefits, including an excellent vacation and sick leave package and a killer healthcare plan (free for a single person, plus flex benefits!)

pros: The environment is fine, you'll work with a lot of different people that change a lot. The work is not hard and overall not bad. Just a lot of standing around sometimes.
cons: This is really just temporary job for students. Don't expect any big perks or "personal growth opportunities"

pros: It was great to get some hands on experience creating videos and motion graphics. You didn't just sit back and help with miniscule tasks. You got to actually have meetings with clients, write scripts, film and edit.
cons: Sometimes it felt as if you were being micromanaged, and received 'check ins' too often to be efficient.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Missoula, MT
pros: The folks at UM want to be there. They are in it for the love of their discipline and their city, not the money or the fame. It’s a pleasant working environment.
cons: The current cost cutting is hitting every department hard, especially the sciences (both hard and soft). Advising has been decimated, and the students are suffering.

pros:
- Easy going work environment 
- Very flexible with student schedules
- Nice to work with people my age
- Flat org structure
cons:
- Boring job and daily activities
- Definitely what one would consider to be a dead end job
- No real opportunities for advancement, not very applicable in my degree

pros: I have worked for the university as a lab monitor for the last year. from this experience I have learned that the university has a good work environment, flexible hours, and excellent training opportunities.
cons: I have worked for the university for the last year. From this experience I have learned that their is no job advancement.  The wage is low too.

pros: Very supportive environment. My time at the University of Montana was very rewarding. The faculties are very accessible and eager to share their experience.
cons: No job security for adjunct professors. The contracts are only for one semester at the time and there are only fewer options to have a career as an adjunct if any.

pros: Great medical benefits, many training opportunities, flexible schedules, in-state tuition waiver, paid holidays, retirement fund, lovely work environment.
cons: Pay is not ideal in the low teens / hour, however when all the pros are taken advantage of (i.e. the savings on education, medical benefits, training opportunities, as well as the retirement fund matched by employer) one ends up investing in their future more so than many other employment opportunities in Missoula.

pros: As if the jaw-dropping natural beauty and amazing culture of Missoula aren't enough, working at UM provides continuous opportunities to explore creative and academic interests through teaching alongside a peerless group of colleagues.
cons: The English Department seemed to sometimes be treated like the redheaded stepchild when it came to funding. Give these geniuses some new furniture, already.

pros: Opportunities are everywhere to do new things in Missoula and around campus. I personally have been able to move up whenever I am ready! I love being an employee and working at UM!
cons: Budgets go up and down, positive experiences can be as contagious as negative ones.

review_title: One of the greatest experiences of my life.
pros: The open minded and creative nature of the people and department I worked in where great! I miss it since I left, and would love a chance to return.
cons: Job stability was always a problem, and changing budgets, and direction seemed to always keep you at the edge of your seat, to see if you would have a job the next semester.

review_title: A wonderful work environment full of wonderful people.
pros: Incredible autonomy is given when interacting with and helping the student customers of this business. These interactions are the most rewarding and educational experiences at this business.
cons: With autonomy comes responsibility, and oversight is sometimes lacking. Employees are trained in policies related to their work, but they must ensure that they are followed.

pros:
- Excellent hours
- Excellent perks
- Great opportunity to build staff relationships
- Looks great on a resume
cons:
- Poor senior management
